selected_quotes: Long-term multi-site pain linked to distress anxiety in adolescents, especially boys

citation.abstract:
Although several studies have shown that adolescent musculoskeletal pain is associated with psychological problems in a cross-sectional setting, the associations of long-term musculoskeletal pain with psychological distress and anxiety are not known.
The study included 1773 adolescents belonging to the Northern Finland Birth Cohort 1986. They received a postal questionnaire at the age of 16years and a follow-up questionnaire two years later. The first inquiry contained questions about the sites of musculoskeletal pain; the second had the same pain questions, along with measures of distress and anxiety. Risk ratios (RR) were assessed by log-linear regression analysis.
Multi-site musculoskeletal pain (in ≥2 body locations) at both 16 and 18years was common, reported by 53% of girls and 30% of boys. Multi-site pain at both ages, compared to those with multi-site pain neither at 16 nor 18years, was associated with psychological distress at the age of 18 among both girls (RR 1.8 95% CI 1.2-2.7) and boys (RR 3.5 95% CI 2.1-5.9). For anxiety, the corresponding relative risks were 1.5 (95% CI 1.0-2.2) and 1.8 (95% CI 1.4-2.3), respectively. For short-term multi-site pain (prevalent only at the age of 16 or 18), these relative risks were between 0.8 and 2.3.
Adolescents with long-term multi-site pain have higher levels of distress and anxiety than those without or with only short-term multi-site pain. Associations were found in both genders, but the relationship between pain and distress was more pronounced among boys. The associations had modest effect strength.
citation.title: Long-term adolescent multi-site musculoskeletal pain is associated with psychological distress and anxiety

author.name: Kate Dunn
author.description: Epidemiology, pain and primary care researcher. Interested in pain in children & over the lifecourse. Views are my own.

author.description: Nurse Practitioner, pediatric pain management, knitting, love to travel! The views expressed here are my own.

author.name: Your Rheum
author.description: A new UK-wide Research Advisory Group specifically for young people aged 11-24 in the UK with a diagnosed rheumatology condition. A BANNAR affiliated group.

author.description: Pain scientist @CprSpine, clinician, #twindad, #benchpresser, #Brummie. Primarily interested in pain & how physical interventions (might) get the better of it.

author.description: Associate professor & Senior researcher at the Research Unit for General Practice in Aalborg, Denmark. Head of the OptiYouth research group.

author.description: Paediatric pain researcher, health psychologist and mother.  All views my own.

author.description: Research interests in the psychology of pain, sex and gender differences in pain, cognition and emotion | pain communication | men's health. Views own etc.
